           <h2>
            WHAT IS MAiSI?
           </h2>
           <p>
            The MAiSI is a full time two year Erasmus Mundus Joint Master Degree in Sports Ethics and Integrity. Innovative and multidisciplinary, the programme is a catalyst for a profession that has been lacking within the sports administration sector. Concentrating on the development of ethical sports cultures and structures, and the development of tools for sports integrity education and compliance, MAiSI is delivered by five prestigious universities in Europe.
           </p>
           <p>
            MAiSI is based on strong theoretical foundations and the development of core competencies needed to develop sports integrity expertise. Scholars are equipped to identify ethical issues, engage in critical ethical thinking, and translate decisions into ethical actions at the highest level of sports governance and administration:
           </p>
           <p>
            Click
            <a href="https://www.maisi-project.eu/masters-degree/">
             here
            </a>

     <section class="section" id="section_653127848">
      <div class="section-bg fill">
      </div>
      <div class="section-content relative">

            <div class="banner-bg fill">
             <img alt="Sports Ethic Master Semester" class="lazy-load bg attachment-large size-large" data-src="https://sp-ao.shortpixel.ai/client/to_webp,q_glossy,ret_img,w_1020,h_680/https://www.maisi-project.eu/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/shutterstock_251794285.jpg" decoding="async" height="680" src="data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20viewBox%3D%220%200%201020%20680%22%20xmlns%3D%22http%3A%2F%2Fwww.w3.org%2F2000%2Fsvg%22%3E%3C%2Fsvg%3E" width="1020"/>

        <div class="col medium-12 small-12 large-6" id="col-139897947">
         <div class="col-inner dark">
          <h2>
           SEMESTER ONE: students to be based at KU Leuven
          </h2>
          <p>
           <strong>
            Sport as a Social Practice:
           </strong>
           Norms and values in sport, athlete welfare and safe sport; equality, diversity, and inclusion; moral psychology of sport; disability and Paralympic ethics.
          </p>
          <p>
           <strong>
            The Nature of Sports Ethics and Ethical Theories:
           </strong>
           Deontological, consequentialist and virtue ethical theories; conventionalist, formalist and internalist theories of sport; key issues such as athletes’ rights, fair play and officiating, homophobia, transgender eligibility.
          </p>
          <p>
           <strong>
            Ethics of Anti-doping and Sport Medicine:
           </strong>
           This covers all ethical aspects for anti-doping policy from its rationale to the implementation of the WADA code and other instruments, but also a critical consideration of the ethics of sports medicine more generally. Key issues for discussion include the whereabouts system and rights to privacy, strict liability, fairness and sanctioning, the Therapeutic Exemption process, as well as respect for the best interests of athlete patients, the goals of sports medicine, and the ethics of clinical decision making.
          </p>
          <p>
           <strong>
            Sports law and integrity regulation
           </strong>
           provides a functional and integrated legal approach to sport, conceived as a social phenomenon with social, economic and cultural impact. Particular attention is paid to the unique nature of sports law, a combination of autonomous sports regulation and public regulation.. The course address:  Sources and principles of sports law; conflict resolution in sport; football labour market integrity; fair trial in dispute resolution; integrity, violence and non- discrimination; sports fraud, competition manipulation and macxh-fixing; the law of anti-doping.
          </p>
          <h2>
           SEMESTER TWO: students to be based at CUNI (Prague). Summer School at UoP (Olympia)
          </h2>
          <p>
           <strong>
            Sport Values, Fair Play and Integrity:
           </strong>
           prioritises the explicit development of philosophical and ethical thinking techniques, with discussions on the nature of sport (analytical approaches to the concept of sport and its values); sport rules (and their functions and characteristics); sport categorisations (especially with respect to issues of fairness and justice); and phenomenological understandings of the athlete as a human being. It also applies these theorisations to practical issues of education for sporting integrity.
          </p>
          <p>
           <strong>
            Issues in Disabilities and Paralympic Sports
           </strong>
           covers the Rehabilitation – Education – Active Lifestyle – Elite Sports continuum, including an examination of the history of parasport as a part of rehabilitation. It explains the importance of recognising biomedical impairment types, and the role of adapted physical activities in the rehabilitation process. It also provides an understanding of elite para sport, its organizational structure, classification, and technologies; and considers associated ethical issues. The educational aspect of the parasport active lifestyle of athletes is also discussed, with field visits and practical activities.
          </p>
          <p>
           <strong>
            Research Methods, Knowledge and Competencies:
           </strong>
           This module is held as part of the summer school and introduces students to the major techniques and methods of data capture in social scientific research. This includes questionnaire design and analysis, qualitative interview and focus group techniques. Students also take part in a “dissertation supermarket” talking with supervisors about potential areas of study for their Master thesis.
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
         </div>

     <section class="section" id="section_1965475056">
      <div class="section-bg fill">
      </div>
      <div class="section-content relative">
       <div class="row row-collapse row-full-width align-middle" id="row-1624648785">
        <div class="col medium-6 small-12 large-6" id="col-1407884554">
         <div class="col-inner">
          <h2>
           SEMESTER THREE: Students to be based at UPF (Barcelona) or JGU (Mainz) depending on their year of entry to the programme
          </h2>
          <p>
           The third semester focuses on in-depth organisational issues that will equip you for the managerial, economic and legal aspects of healthy sports governance. You will also begin your Master thesis in this semester. This entails research topic selection, developing research problems and questions, literature review and preparation of research ethics applications. This semester also focusses on ethical decision making and the challenges international sport federations and major sport event organisers face.
          </p>
          <h2>
           SEMESTER FOUR: Students to be based at any of the Consortium partners depending on their thesis specialism. Summer School at UoP (Olympia)
          </h2>
          <p>
           During the fourth semester, you will have the benefit of being hosted by one of the MAiSI consortium partners to complete your Master thesis. Semester 4 also includes your final taught module in Olympic studies, which is taught as part of the Summer School, and incorporates sites of historical interest from the Ancient Olympic period.
          </p>
         </div>

        <div class="text" id="text-1876176306">
         <h3>
          JOIN A POWERFUL NETWORK OF SECTOR CUSTODIANS
         </h3>
         <style>
          #text-1876176306 {
  font-size: 1.45rem;
  text-align: left;
}
         </style>
        </div>
        <p>
         Through the completion of your EMJMD in Sports Ethics and Integrity (MAiSI), you will join a powerful, international network of partnerships and stakeholders. This network, through their varied roles in the sporting sector, are deeply committed to the promoting of critical engagement and ethical dialogue around the issues facing sports administrations in relation to managing their sports ethics and integrity functions.
        </p>

         <div class="col-inner">
          <div class="text" id="text-910030691">
           <h2>
            WHAT IS MAiSI?
           </h2>
           <p>
            The MAiSI is a full time two year Erasmus Mundus Joint Master Degree in Sports Ethics and Integrity. Innovative and multidisciplinary, the programme is a catalyst for a profession that has been lacking within the sports administration sector. Concentrating on the development of ethical sports cultures and structures, and the development of tools for sports integrity education and compliance, MAiSI is delivered by five prestigious universities in Europe.
           </p>
           <p>
            MAiSI is based on strong theoretical foundations and the development of core competencies needed to develop sports integrity expertise. Scholars are equipped to identify ethical issues, engage in critical ethical thinking, and translate decisions into ethical actions at the highest level of sports governance and administration:
           </p>
           <p>
            Click
            <a href="https://www.maisi-project.eu/masters-degree/">
             here
            </a>
            for more information about the study program, funding and application.
           </p>
           <style>
            #text-910030691 {
  font-size: 1.1rem;
}
           </style>

     <section class="section" id="section_122761942">
      <div class="section-bg fill">
      </div>
      <div class="section-content relative">
       <div class="row row-collapse row-full-width align-middle" id="row-1285700015">
        <div class="col medium-12 small-12 large-6" id="col-1590337306">
         <div class="col-inner">
          <div class="banner has-hover" id="banner-1428200125">
           <div class="banner-inner fill">
            <div class="banner-bg fill">
             <img alt="Sports Ethic Master Semester" class="lazy-load bg attachment-large size-large" data-src="https://sp-ao.shortpixel.ai/client/to_webp,q_glossy,ret_img,w_1020,h_680/https://www.maisi-project.eu/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/shutterstock_251794285.jpg" decoding="async" height="680" src="data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20viewBox%3D%220%200%201020%20680%22%20xmlns%3D%22http%3A%2F%2Fwww.w3.org%2F2000%2Fsvg%22%3E%3C%2Fsvg%3E" width="1020"/>

        <div class="col medium-12 small-12 large-6" id="col-1986605784">
         <div class="col-inner dark">
          <h2>
           SEMESTER ONE: students to be based at KU Leuven
          </h2>
          <p>
           <strong>
            Sport as a Social Practice:
           </strong>
           Norms and values in sport, athlete welfare and safe sport; equality, diversity, and inclusion; moral psychology of sport; disability and Paralympic ethics.
          </p>
          <p>
           <strong>
            The Nature of Sports Ethics and Ethical Theories:
           </strong>
           Deontological, consequentialist and virtue ethical theories; conventionalist, formalist and internalist theories of sport; key issues such as athletes’ rights, fair play and officiating, homophobia, transgender eligibility.
          </p>
          <p>
           <strong>
            Ethics of Anti-doping and Sport Medicine:
           </strong>
           This covers all ethical aspects for anti-doping policy from its rationale to the implementation of the WADA code and other instruments, but also a critical consideration of the ethics of sports medicine more generally. Key issues for discussion include the whereabouts system and rights to privacy, strict liability, fairness and sanctioning, the Therapeutic Exemption process, as well as respect for the best interests of athlete patients, the goals of sports medicine, and the ethics of clinical decision making.
          </p>
          <p>
           <strong>
            Sports law and integrity regulation
           </strong>
           provides a functional and integrated legal approach to sport, conceived as a social phenomenon with social, economic and cultural impact. Particular attention is paid to the unique nature of sports law, a combination of autonomous sports regulation and public regulation.. The course address:  Sources and principles of sports law; conflict resolution in sport; football labour market integrity; fair trial in dispute resolution; integrity, violence and non- discrimination; sports fraud, competition manipulation and macxh-fixing; the law of anti-doping.
          </p>
          <h2>
           SEMESTER TWO: students to be based at CUNI (Prague). Summer School at UoP (Olympia)
          </h2>
          <p>
           <strong>
            Sport Values, Fair Play and Integrity:
           </strong>
           prioritises the explicit development of philosophical and ethical thinking techniques, with discussions on the nature of sport (analytical approaches to the concept of sport and its values); sport rules (and their functions and characteristics); sport categorisations (especially with respect to issues of fairness and justice); and phenomenological understandings of the athlete as a human being. It also applies these theorisations to practical issues of education for sporting integrity.
          </p>
          <p>
           <strong>
            Issues in Disabilities and Paralympic Sports
           </strong>
           covers the Rehabilitation – Education – Active Lifestyle – Elite Sports continuum, including an examination of the history of parasport as a part of rehabilitation. It explains the importance of recognising biomedical impairment types, and the role of adapted physical activities in the rehabilitation process. It also provides an understanding of elite para sport, its organizational structure, classification, and technologies; and considers associated ethical issues. The educational aspect of the parasport active lifestyle of athletes is also discussed, with field visits and practical activities.
          </p>
          <p>
           <strong>
            Research Methods, Knowledge and Competencies:
           </strong>
           This module is held as part of the summer school and introduces students to the major techniques and methods of data capture in social scientific research. This includes questionnaire design and analysis, qualitative interview and focus group techniques. Students also take part in a “dissertation supermarket” talking with supervisors about potential areas of study for their Master thesis.
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
         </div>

     <section class="section" id="section_266028674">
      <div class="section-bg fill">
      </div>
      <div class="section-content relative">
       <div class="row row-collapse row-full-width align-middle" id="row-1266423973">
        <div class="col medium-6 small-12 large-6" id="col-592294608">
         <div class="col-inner">
          <h2>
           SEMESTER THREE: Students to be based at UPF (Barcelona) or JGU (Mainz) depending on their year of entry to the programme
          </h2>
          <p>
           The third semester focuses on in-depth organisational issues that will equip you for the managerial, economic and legal aspects of healthy sports governance. You will also begin your Master thesis in this semester. This entails research topic selection, developing research problems and questions, literature review and preparation of research ethics applications. This semester also focusses on ethical decision making and the challenges international sport federations and major sport event organisers face.
          </p>
          <h2>
           SEMESTER FOUR: Students to be based at any of the Consortium partners depending on their thesis specialism. Summer School at UoP (Olympia)
          </h2>
          <p>
           During the fourth semester, you will have the benefit of being hosted by one of the MAiSI consortium partners to complete your Master thesis. Semester 4 also includes your final taught module in Olympic studies, which is taught as part of the Summer School, and incorporates sites of historical interest from the Ancient Olympic period.
          </p>

        <div class="text" id="text-1164360208">
         <h3>
          JOIN A POWERFUL NETWORK OF SECTOR CUSTODIANS
         </h3>
         <style>
          #text-1164360208 {
  font-size: 1.45rem;
  text-align: left;
}
         </style>
        </div>
        <p>
         Through the completion of your EMJMD in Sports Ethics and Integrity (MAiSI), you will join a powerful, international network of partnerships and stakeholders. This network, through their varied roles in the sporting sector, are deeply committed to the promoting of critical engagement and ethical dialogue around the issues facing sports administrations in relation to managing their sports ethics and integrity functions.
        </p>

     <div class="cmplz-message" id="cmplz-message-1-optin">
      To provide the best experiences, we use technologies like cookies to store and/or access device information. Consenting to these technologies will allow us to process data such as browsing behavior or unique IDs on this site. Not consenting or withdrawing consent, may adversely affect certain features and functions.
     </div>

         <span class="cmplz-always-active">
          <span class="cmplz-banner-checkbox">

          </span>

           <h2 style="padding-top: 20px;">
            Program Description & Content
           </h2>
           <p style="padding-top: 20px;">
            The Master’s Degree
            <strong>
             MAiSI
            </strong>
            will equip students for high-level careers in sports administration and governance, with a focus on ethical sports, integrity and compliance. Students will receive training that enables them to identify ethical issues, engage in moral thinking, and translate decisions into moral actions – the three core skills required to develop sports integrity.
           </p>
           <p>
            Students will be based in Mainz or Barcelona, in alternating years (intake 2024: Mainz; intake 2025: Barcelona; etc…).
           </p>
           <p>
            The
            <strong>
             MAiSI
            </strong>
            will support students in developing an ethical mind-set and transferable skills that are indispensable for addressing the value and integrity issues facing national and international sporting federations, national Olympic Committees, and Paralympic Committees with a focus on:
           </p>

            1st Year – MAiSI Master’s Degree

           <p>
            Master of Arts (MA) in Sports Ethics and Integrity
           </p>
          </div>
          <div aria-labelledby="tab-entry-requirements" class="panel entry-content" id="tab_entry-requirements" role="tabpanel">
           <h2 style="padding-top: 20px;">
            Entry Requirements
           </h2>
           <h3 style="padding-top: 20px;">
            Degree requirements:
           </h3>
           <p>
            The Erasmus Mundus MA in Sports Ethics and Integrity (MAiSI) requires successful applicants to hold a Bachelor’s degree. Due to the inter-disciplinary nature of the course we will consider applications from any degree discipline. Degree subject areas of particular relevance to the Masters in Sports Ethics and Integrity are Business, Management, Disability Studies, Ethics, Governance, History, Law, Philosophy, Social Sciences, Sports and Exercise Sciences. However, this is not an exhaustive list.
           </p>
           <h3>
            Language requirements:
           </h3>
           <p>
            All applicants who have not obtained a previous diploma in a programme taught in English in Australia, English-speaking Canada, Ireland, New Zealand, the United Kingdom and the United States of America must submit a certificate proving their proficiency in English.
           </p>
           <p>
            A list of tests accepted by KU Leuven can be found on:
           </p>
           <p>
            <a href="https://www.kuleuven.be/english/apply/language-requirements" rel="noopener" target="_blank">
             https://www.kuleuven.be/english/admissions/lang/lang-test
            </a>
           </p>
           <p>
            The required minimum IELTS score is an overall 6.5 (and no component below 5.5).
           </p>
           <p>
            The required minimum TOEFL score is 80 on TOEFL IBT (and no component below 19)
           </p>
           <p>
            The required minimum score for Cambridge Assessment English is an overall C1 Advanced (CAE) or C2 Proficiency (CPE) score of 176. The B2 First (FCE) is not accepted by KU Leuven.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div aria-labelledby="tab-application-&-selection-process" class="panel entry-content" id="tab_application-&-selection-process" role="tabpanel">
           <h2 style="padding-top: 20px;">
            Application & Selection Process
           </h2>
           <h3 style="padding-top: 20px;">
            Application procedure:
           </h3>
           <p>
            Applicants will need to follow the application procedure of the KU Leuven Admissions Office. Instructions can be found on
            <a href="https://www.kuleuven.be/english/application/instructions" rel="noopener" target="_blank">
             https://www.kuleuven.be/english/application/instructions
            </a>
            . KU Leuven requires an application processing fee of EUR 90. This amount is nonrefundable.
           </p>
           <p>
            Your application will be rejected if you do not submit the relevant supporting documents with your application form:
           </p>
           <ul>
            <li>
             PDF scans of your diploma(s) and transcripts of academic records
             <ul>
              <li>
               If you still need to graduate at the time of your application, you are requested to upload PDF scans of your intermediate official transcripts through the web application portal.
              </li>
              <li>
               The Admissions Office reserves the right to ask for official or certified hard copies of transcripts (or diplomas) if required for the evaluation of the application.
              </li>
             </ul>
            </li>
            <li>
             PDF scan of the translation of your diploma(s) and official transcripts If your documents are not in English, Dutch, French or German, please arrange for these documents to be translated by a registered translator. These documents must also be certified by the educational institution that issued them or by a national authority.
            </li>
            <li>
             Motivation letter (one A4 page): A personal statement detailing your reasons for applying to the course and relevant experience academic and otherwise
            </li>
            <li>
             Your English Language test certificates (i.e IELTS/TOEFL) if appropriate
            </li>
            <li>
             Two recommendation letter/references (at least one academical): Please use the official letterhead paper of the institution or company and upload the letters to your online application file. If you already hold open references, then please upload them with your application. Alternatively, please ask your referees to send their letters of support directly to the Admissions Office (
             <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#f091949d998383999f9e83b09b859c958586959ede9295">
              <span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="1273767f7b61617b7d7c615279677e776764777c3c7077">
               [email protected]
              </span>
             </a>
             ).
            </li>
            <li>
             Your Curriculum Vitae
            </li>
            <li>
             Proof of nationality (copy of passport)
            </li>
           </ul>
           <h3>
            Selection process:
           </h3>
           <p>
            Applications will be selected based on the entry and language requirements. Those eligible will then be judged according to Academic Excellence:
           </p>
           <ul>
            <li>
             Experience related to the course (academic)
            </li>
            <li>
             Relevant work experience
            </li>
            <li>
             Motivation and understanding of the course
            </li>
           </ul>
           <p>
            A selection of candidates will then be interviewed online. The offer of waivers, IOC scholarships and self-funded places will be made having considered performance at interview, the above criteria. and restrictions regarding the number of waivers and IOC scholarships that can be allocated to applicants from designated regional windows. Deadlines and timetable for selection for the intake of September are:
           </p>
           <table>
            <tbody>
             <tr>
              <td>
               <strong>
                IOC – Olympic Solidarity scholarship & Non-EEA citizens applications:
               </strong>
              </td>
              <td>
               <strong>
                April 1st
               </strong>
              </td>
             </tr>
             <tr>
              <td>
               <strong>
                EEA citizens:
               </strong>
              </td>
              <td>
               <strong>
                July 1st
               </strong>
              </td>
             </tr>
            </tbody>
           </table>
           <p>
            <strong>
             Full waivers application process (non-EEA):
            </strong>
           </p>
           <ul>
            <li>
             Start application: October 20th
            </li>
            <li>
             Deadline for applications: April 1st
            </li>
            <li>
             Ranking of applications and interviews will be completed one month after the application deadline
            </li>
            <li>
             Awarding of scholarships May 1st
            </li>
           </ul>
           <p>
            <strong>
             IOC Scholarship/Non-scholarship application process:
            </strong>
           </p>
           <ul>
            <li>
             Start application: October 20th
            </li>
            <li>
             Deadlines for applications: April 1st (for IOC scholarships/ non-EEA citizens) / July 1st (for EEA citizens)
            </li>
            <li>
             Ranking of applications and interviews will be completed one month after the application deadline
            </li>
            <li>
             Awarding of admissions: July 1st at the latest
            </li>
           </ul>
           <p>
            <strong>
             Please note: The data you provide in applying for the Erasmus Mundus Joint Masters in Sports Ethics and Integrity be used by other bodies involved in the management of EMJMD acting as stakeholders of the programme (i.e. European Commission, Erasmus+ National Offices, EU Delegations, Erasmus Mundus Students and Alumni Association) for facilitating the student access to the joint programme.
            </strong>
           </p>
          </div>
          <div aria-labelledby="tab-maisi-funding" class="panel entry-content" id="tab_maisi-funding" role="tabpanel">
           <h2 style="padding-top: 20px;">
            MAiSI Funding
           </h2>
           <p>
            This list gives an overview of the current funding opportunities available to MAISI students.
            <br/>
            <strong>
             For the academic year 2025-2026, no Erasmus Mundus scholarships are available.
            </strong>
           </p>
           <p>
            <strong>
             General and KU Leuven scholarships
            </strong>
           </p>
           <p>
            Find an overview of all available options on
            <a href="https://www.kuleuven.be/scholarships/year#c5=Academic%20year%202025-2026&b_start=0">
             the KU Leuven website.
            </a>
           </p>
           <p>
            Every MAISI student who does not receive funding from the European Union, can apply for the KU Leuven Mobility Erasmus+ Scholarship. Once you are accepted into the MAiSI programme, your application will be created automatically.
            <br/>
            <br/>
            More information, including the scholarship amounts for the academic year 2024-2025, can be found
            <a href="https://www.kuleuven.be/english/education/student/outgoing-mobility/scholarshipamounts2024-2025">
             here
            </a>
            .
           </p>
           <p>
            <strong>
             IOC Olympic Solidarity scholarship
            </strong>
           </p>
           <p>
            Application is only possible once you have been admitted to the MAiSI programme and if you obtained endorsement from your National Olympic Committee (NOC). Once approved, your NOC will submit application on the OS RELAY platform.
           </p>
           <p>
            More information on Olympic Solidarity can be found on the folliwing on:
            <br/>
            <a href="https://olympics.com/athlete365/topics/olympic-solidarity">
             Olympics.com
            </a>
            and
            <a href="https://olympians.org/news/1829/apply-today-for-fully-funded-masters-in-sport-ethics-and-integrity/">
             Olympians.org
            </a>
            .
           </p>
           <p>
            <strong>
             JGU & UoP scholarships
            </strong>
           </p>
           <table>
            <tbody>
             <tr>
              <td>
               <strong>
                Deutschlandstipendium
               </strong>
              </td>
              <td>
               Scholarship holders receive +/- 300 € per month for 1 year. Half of the scholarship money is paid by a sponsor (company, private person, foundation) and half by the Federal Ministry of Education and Research. Beyond the financial means, the scholarship holders get the opportunity to establish contacts with the sponsors.
               <br/>
               Click
               <a href="https://www.foerdern-und-stiften.uni-mainz.de/deutschlandstipendium/informationen-fuer-foerderer/" rel="noopener" target="_blank">
                here
               </a>
               for more information (no English website available, only in German).
              </td>
             </tr>
             <tr>
              <td>
               <strong>
                Scholarships for finalizing a degree with DAAD
               </strong>
              </td>
              <td>
               Foreign students at the JGU who have obtained their certificate for admission to higher education not in Germany and who are about to finish their studies are invited to apply for scholarships for degree-finalization (in the final phase of their studies of their Bachelor, Master, State Examination, Ph.D.) financed by the German Academic Exchange Service (DAAD). For more information please contact: International Office, Studienbegleitprogramm JGU
               <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#cdbea8bfbba4aea88da4a3b9a8bfa3acb9a4a2a3aca1e3b8a3a4e0a0aca4a3b7e3a9a8">
                <span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="384b5d4a4e515b5d7851564c5d4a56594c5157565954164d5651155559515642165c5d">
                 [email protected]
                </span>
               </a>
              </td>
             </tr>
             <tr>
              <td>
               <strong>
                Scholarships John S. Latsis Public Benefit
               </strong>
               <br/>
               <strong>
                Foundation
               </strong>
              </td>
              <td>
               Click
               <a href="https://www.latsis-foundation.org/eng/scholarships" rel="noopener" target="_blank">
                here
               </a>
               for more information.
               <br/>
               John S. Latsis Public Benefit Foundation is annually implementing its Postgraduate Scholarships Programme aiming to support postgraduate students in higher educational institutes in Greece and abroad at Master&#39;s level.
              </td>
             </tr>
            </tbody>
           </table>
          </div>
          <div aria-labelledby="tab-costs-&-fees" class="panel entry-content" id="tab_costs-&-fees" role="tabpanel">
           <h2 style="padding-top: 20px;">
            MAiSI Costs and fees
           </h2>
           <p>
            The total tuition fee costs for the whole two year programme are as follows:
           </p>
           <ul>
            <li>
             EUR 6000 for applicants with EEA nationality
            </li>
            <li>
             EUR 12000 for applicants with non-EEA nationality
            </li>
           </ul>
           <p>
            These fees cover tuition from world leading academics in the field of sports ethics and integrity. Extra costs will include accommodation, travel, living costs, and funds for course materials.
           </p>
           <p>
            Kindly refer to
            <a href="https://www.kuleuven.be/english/life-at-ku-leuven/" rel="noopener" target="_blank">
             https://www.kuleuven.be/english/life-at-ku-leuven/
            </a>
            for information on life at KU Leuven (estimated costs of living). The MAiSI programme starts in Leuven (Belgium) and the entire cohort will be based there during the first semester of the first year.
           </p>
          </div>

          <div aria-labelledby="tab-internships" class="panel entry-content" id="tab_internships" role="tabpanel">
           <h2 style="padding-top: 20px;">
            Internships
           </h2>
           <p style="padding-top: 20px;">
            <b>
             MAiSI
            </b>
            supports its students to secure internships, although these are not a formal element of the curriculum. The faculty of the MAiSI Consortium have extensive international networks and will help you to look for suitable internships. Since commencing in 2017, our students have secured internships at
            <b>
             Athletics Integrity Unit
            </b>
            ,
            <b>
             British Horseracing Authority
            </b>
            ,
            <b>
             Fédération Française du Sport Universitaire
            </b>
            ,
            <b>
             International Center for Ethics in Sport
            </b>
            ,
            <b>
             International Olympic Committee
            </b>
            ,
            <b>
             International Ice Hockey Federation
            </b>
            ,
            <b>
             International Tennis Federation
            </b>
            ,
            <b>
             International Testing Agency
            </b>
            ,
            <b>
             Royal Belgian Football Association
            </b>
            ,
            <b>
             United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime
            </b>
            ,
            <b>
             Institute of National Anti Doping Organisations
            </b>
            and the
            <b>
             World Anti Doping Agency
            </b>
            .
           </p>
           <p>
            The purpose of the
            <a href="https://www.maisi-project.eu/alumni/">
             MAiSI alumni
            </a>
            is among other things to provide further opportunities to alumni for professional and academic development.
           </p>
          </div>

     <div class="row" id="row-1636711767">
      <div class="col small-12 large-12" id="col-199437187">
       <div class="col-inner">
        <h2>
         Collaborations with Universities
        </h2>
        <h3>
         This course is a product of an international collaboration of the following universities:
        </h3>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="row" id="row-146575967">
      <div class="col small-12 large-12" id="col-1651298178">
       <div class="col-inner">
        <div class="tabbed-content">
         <ul class="nav nav-tabs nav-vertical nav-normal nav-size-large nav-left" role="tablist">
          <li class="tab active has-icon" id="tab-ku-leuven" role="presentation">
           <a aria-controls="tab_ku-leuven" aria-selected="true" href="#tab_ku-leuven" role="tab">
            <span>
             KU Leuven
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="tab has-icon" id="tab-charles-university" role="presentation">
           <a aria-controls="tab_charles-university" aria-selected="false" href="#tab_charles-university" role="tab" tabindex="-1">
            <span>
             Charles University
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="tab has-icon" id="tab-johannes-gutenberg-university-mainz" role="presentation">
           <a aria-controls="tab_johannes-gutenberg-university-mainz" aria-selected="false" href="#tab_johannes-gutenberg-university-mainz" role="tab" tabindex="-1">
            <span>
             Johannes Gutenberg University Mainz
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="tab has-icon" id="tab-swansea-university" role="presentation">
           <a aria-controls="tab_swansea-university" aria-selected="false" href="#tab_swansea-university" role="tab" tabindex="-1">
            <span>
             Swansea University
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="tab has-icon" id="tab-university-of-the-peloponnese" role="presentation">
           <a aria-controls="tab_university-of-the-peloponnese" aria-selected="false" href="#tab_university-of-the-peloponnese" role="tab" tabindex="-1">
            <span>
             University of the Peloponnese
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="tab has-icon" id="tab-university-pompeu-fabra" role="presentation">
           <a aria-controls="tab_university-pompeu-fabra" aria-selected="false" href="#tab_university-pompeu-fabra" role="tab" tabindex="-1">
            <span>
             University Pompeu Fabra
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
         </ul>
         <div class="tab-panels">
          <div aria-labelledby="tab-ku-leuven" class="panel active entry-content" id="tab_ku-leuven" role="tabpanel">
           <p style="padding-top: 20px">
            <strong>
             KU Leuven,
            </strong>
            founded in 1425, is one of the oldest Universities in the world, and ranks among the world’s top 100 Universities. It is a leading centre of international excellence in disability and Paralympic sport.
           </p>
           <p>
            See our Research school
            <a href="https://www.kuleuven.be/iceris" rel="noopener" target="_blank">
             here
            </a>
            .
           </p>
          </div>
          <div aria-labelledby="tab-charles-university" class="panel entry-content" id="tab_charles-university" role="tabpanel">
           <p style="padding-top: 20px">
            <strong>
             Charles University
            </strong>
            in Prague, founded in 1348, is the oldest University in Central Europe, and is consistently ranked first among the Universities of Central and Eastern Europe.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div aria-labelledby="tab-johannes-gutenberg-university-mainz" class="panel entry-content" id="tab_johannes-gutenberg-university-mainz" role="tabpanel">
           <p style="padding-top: 20px">
            <strong>
             Johannes Gutenberg University Mainz,
            </strong>
            founded in 1477, is one of the top research universities in Germany of national and international recognition. It is a founding partner of the groundbreaking Executive Master in European Sports Governance.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div aria-labelledby="tab-swansea-university" class="panel entry-content" id="tab_swansea-university" role="tabpanel">
           <p style="padding-top: 20px">
            <strong>
             Swansea University,
            </strong>
            founded in 1920, is a rapidly growing, UK top 30, research-intensive University with world-leading sports science research and productive international partnerships. Swansea has pioneered globally the ethics of sports as an area of applied research and consultancy in elite sport. From 2024 onwards (cohort 8) following the UK exit from EU-28, Swansea University will no longer be a former partner.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div aria-labelledby="tab-university-of-the-peloponnese" class="panel entry-content" id="tab_university-of-the-peloponnese" role="tabpanel">
           <p style="padding-top: 20px">
            The
            <strong>
             University of the Peloponnese
            </strong>
            is the most recently founded of Greek Universities, and draws on extensive links with the International Olympic Academy and the Olympic Movement. It hosts summer schools on Olympic Studies at its Ancient Olympia campus, adjacent to the archaeological site of the Ancient Olympic Games.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div aria-labelledby="tab-university-pompeu-fabra" class="panel entry-content" id="tab_university-pompeu-fabra" role="tabpanel">
           <p style="padding-top: 20px;">
            The
            <strong>
             University Pompeu Fabra
            </strong>
            is ranked as the 1st University in Spain, the 7th in Europe and 13th worldwide in the Times Higher Education (THE) top Universities under 50 years old. It is recognised as a “Campus of International Excellence”‌‌‌.
           </p>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>

       <div class="row" id="row-56784937">
        <div class="col small-12 large-12" id="col-461461824">
         <div class="col-inner">
          <div class="text" id="text-2766926147">
           <h2>
            WHAT IS MAiSI?
           </h2>
           <p>
            The MAiSI is a full time two year Erasmus Mundus Joint Master Degree in Sports Ethics and Integrity. Innovative and multidisciplinary, the programme is a catalyst for a profession that has been lacking within the sports administration sector. Concentrating on the development of ethical sports cultures and structures, and the development of tools for sports integrity education and compliance, MAiSI is delivered by five prestigious universities in Europe.
           </p>
           <p>
            MAiSI is based on strong theoretical foundations and the development of core competencies needed to develop sports integrity expertise. Scholars are equipped to identify ethical issues, engage in critical ethical thinking, and translate decisions into ethical actions at the highest level of sports governance and administration:
           </p>
           <p>
            Click
            <a href="https://www.maisi-project.eu/masters-degree/">
             here
            </a>
            for more information about the study program, funding and application.
           </p>
           <style>
            #text-2766926147 {
  font-size: 1.1rem;
}
           </style>
          </div>
         </div>

        <div class="col medium-12 small-12 large-6" id="col-1730764088">
         <div class="col-inner dark">
          <h2>
           SEMESTER ONE: students to be based at KU Leuven
          </h2>
          <p>
           <strong>
            Sport as a Social Practice:
           </strong>
           Norms and values in sport, athlete welfare and safe sport; equality, diversity, and inclusion; moral psychology of sport; disability and Paralympic ethics.
          </p>
          <p>
           <strong>
            The Nature of Sports Ethics and Ethical Theories:
           </strong>
           Deontological, consequentialist and virtue ethical theories; conventionalist, formalist and internalist theories of sport; key issues such as athletes’ rights, fair play and officiating, homophobia, transgender eligibility.
          </p>
          <p>
           <strong>
            Ethics of Anti-doping and Sport Medicine:
           </strong>
           This covers all ethical aspects for anti-doping policy from its rationale to the implementation of the WADA code and other instruments, but also a critical consideration of the ethics of sports medicine more generally. Key issues for discussion include the whereabouts system and rights to privacy, strict liability, fairness and sanctioning, the Therapeutic Exemption process, as well as respect for the best interests of athlete patients, the goals of sports medicine, and the ethics of clinical decision making.
          </p>
          <p>
           <strong>
            Sports law and integrity regulation
           </strong>
           provides a functional and integrated legal approach to sport, conceived as a social phenomenon with social, economic and cultural impact. Particular attention is paid to the unique nature of sports law, a combination of autonomous sports regulation and public regulation.. The course address:  Sources and principles of sports law; conflict resolution in sport; football labour market integrity; fair trial in dispute resolution; integrity, violence and non- discrimination; sports fraud, competition manipulation and macxh-fixing; the law of anti-doping.
          </p>
          <h2>
           SEMESTER TWO: students to be based at CUNI (Prague). Summer School at UoP (Olympia)
          </h2>
          <p>
           <strong>
            Sport Values, Fair Play and Integrity:
           </strong>
           prioritises the explicit development of philosophical and ethical thinking techniques, with discussions on the nature of sport (analytical approaches to the concept of sport and its values); sport rules (and their functions and characteristics); sport categorisations (especially with respect to issues of fairness and justice); and phenomenological understandings of the athlete as a human being. It also applies these theorisations to practical issues of education for sporting integrity.
          </p>
          <p>
           <strong>
            Issues in Disabilities and Paralympic Sports
           </strong>
           covers the Rehabilitation – Education – Active Lifestyle – Elite Sports continuum, including an examination of the history of parasport as a part of rehabilitation. It explains the importance of recognising biomedical impairment types, and the role of adapted physical activities in the rehabilitation process. It also provides an understanding of elite para sport, its organizational structure, classification, and technologies; and considers associated ethical issues. The educational aspect of the parasport active lifestyle of athletes is also discussed, with field visits and practical activities.
          </p>
          <p>
           <strong>
            Research Methods, Knowledge and Competencies:
           </strong>
           This module is held as part of the summer school and introduces students to the major techniques and methods of data capture in social scientific research. This includes questionnaire design and analysis, qualitative interview and focus group techniques. Students also take part in a “dissertation supermarket” talking with supervisors about potential areas of study for their Master thesis.
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
         </div>

     <section class="section" id="section_1572651228">
      <div class="section-bg fill">
      </div>
      <div class="section-content relative">
       <div class="row row-collapse row-full-width align-middle" id="row-1286397376">
        <div class="col medium-6 small-12 large-6" id="col-1575925604">
         <div class="col-inner">
          <h2>
           SEMESTER THREE: Students to be based at UPF (Barcelona) or JGU (Mainz) depending on their year of entry to the programme
          </h2>
          <p>
           The third semester focuses on in-depth organisational issues that will equip you for the managerial, economic and legal aspects of healthy sports governance. You will also begin your Master thesis in this semester. This entails research topic selection, developing research problems and questions, literature review and preparation of research ethics applications. This semester also focusses on ethical decision making and the challenges international sport federations and major sport event organisers face.
          </p>
          <h2>
           SEMESTER FOUR: Students to be based at any of the Consortium partners depending on their thesis specialism. Summer School at UoP (Olympia)
          </h2>
          <p>
           During the fourth semester, you will have the benefit of being hosted by one of the MAiSI consortium partners to complete your Master thesis. Semester 4 also includes your final taught module in Olympic studies, which is taught as part of the Summer School, and incorporates sites of historical interest from the Ancient Olympic period.
          </p>
         </div>

        <div class="text" id="text-3200880395">
         <h3>
          JOIN A POWERFUL NETWORK OF SECTOR CUSTODIANS
         </h3>
         <style>
          #text-3200880395 {
  font-size: 1.45rem;
  text-align: left;
}
         </style>
        </div>
        <p>
         Through the completion of your EMJMD in Sports Ethics and Integrity (MAiSI), you will join a powerful, international network of partnerships and stakeholders. This network, through their varied roles in the sporting sector, are deeply committed to the promoting of critical engagement and ethical dialogue around the issues facing sports administrations in relation to managing their sports ethics and integrity functions.
        </p>

     <div class="row" id="row-268810529">
      <div class="col small-12 large-12" id="col-326266777">
       <div class="col-inner">
        <h2>
         MAiSI Alumni Network
        </h2>
        <p>
         MAISI alumni have nominated their Officers for the coming year as the network continues to grow and develop. The results of the process are as follows:
        </p>
        <ul>
         <li>
          <strong>
           Alumni Director:
          </strong>
          Whitney Bragagnolo
         </li>
         <li>
          <strong>
           President:
          </strong>
          Aline Lopes da Silva Candeo
         </li>
         <li>
          <strong>
           MAiSI Alumni – Liaison:
          </strong>
          Ayça Gürsoy
         </li>
         <li>
          <strong>
           MAiSI Alumni – Liaison:
          </strong>
          Osazemen Aghedo
         </li>
        </ul>
        <p>
         The purpose of the network is to provide a platform to enable MAISI alumni to stay in touch and provide mutual support; to help keep alumni connected to the MAISI university consortium; and to provide further opportunities to alumni for professional and academic development. The network is run by and for MAISI alumni and is supported on behalf of the universities faculty by Dr Andy Harvey from Swansea University.
        </p>
        <p>
         <strong>
          Website:
         </strong>
         <a href="https://www.themaisialumni.com/" rel="noopener" target="_blank">
          www.themaisialumni.com
         </a>
         <br/>
         <strong>
          Email alumni:
         </strong>
         <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#432e222a302a222f362e2d2a03242e222a2f6d202c2e">
          <span class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="2a474b4359434b465f4744436a4d474b434604494547">
           [email protected]
          </span>
         </a>
        </p>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>

     <div class="row" id="row-550412174">
      <div class="col small-12 large-12" id="col-308066440">
       <div class="col-inner">
        <h2>
         Global network for sports ethics and integrity
        </h2>
        <p>
         MAiSI is supported by a plethora of World leading organisations and International Federations some of whom are sponsoring a diverse cohort of students to become part of the Global network for sports ethics and integrity.
        </p>
        <p>
         For more information on how to become a corporate sponsor of MAiSI please contact Professor Mike McNamee on +44 (0)1792 513385
        </p>
        <a class="button secondary" href="https://www.maisi-project.eu/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/pdfresizer.com-pdf-resize.pdf" rel="noopener" target="_blank">
         <span>
          Download PDF
         </span>
        </a>
        <div class="gap-element clearfix" id="gap-363937621" style="display:block; height:auto;">

        <div class="img has-hover x md-x lg-x y md-y lg-y" id="image_1916718087">
         <div class="img-inner dark">
          <img alt="Sponsor: Olympic Solidarity" class="lazy-load attachment-large size-large" data-src="https://sp-ao.shortpixel.ai/client/to_webp,q_glossy,ret_img,w_200,h_200/https://www.maisi-project.eu/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/olympic.png" decoding="async" height="200" src="data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20viewBox%3D%220%200%20200%20200%22%20xmlns%3D%22http%3A%2F%2Fwww.w3.org%2F2000%2Fsvg%22%3E%3C%2Fsvg%3E" width="200"/>

}

        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="col medium-9 small-12 large-9" id="col-196924693">
       <div class="col-inner">
        <h3>
         Olympic Solidarity
        </h3>
        <p>
         The world governing body
        </p>
        <p>
         Olympic Solidarity is a programme of the International Olympic Committee (IOC) and its mission is to provide assistance to National Olympic Committees (NOCs) around the world for athlete development, in particular those with the greatest need of it, in order that NOCs may fulfil their responsibilities to the Olympic Movement while adhering to the IOC strategy.
        </p>
        <p>
         This assistance takes the form of multi-faceted programmes prioritising athletes, but also training of coaches and sports administrators, and promoting Olympic Values. These programmes are elaborated jointly by the IOC and the NOCs, with the technical assistance of the International Federations, if necessary. The mission of Olympic Solidarity is enshrined in Rule 5 (and its bye-laws) of the Olympic Charter.
        </p>
        <p>
         or more information on Olympic Solidarity, please visit:
         <a href="https://www.maisi-project.eu/corporate-sponsors/" rel="noopener" target="_blank">
          olympic.org/olympic-solidarity
         </a>
        </p>
        <p>
         Olympic Solidarity supports several Olympian students.
        </p>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="col small-12 large-12" id="col-49914526">
       <div class="col-inner">
        <div class="is-divider divider clearfix" style="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px;max-width:100%;">
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="row" id="row-1881436603">
      <div class="col medium-3 small-12 large-3" id="col-1900080117">

       <div class="col-inner">
        <h3>
         Enigma Alliance (part of the Chelsea Group)
        </h3>
        <p>
         With a focus on entrepreneurship and business development, technology-innovative projects and start ups, Enigma Alliance is a group of companies that offers a world-class capability in a variety of key disciplines. Enigma Alliance was created in 2013 by Stuart Page (CEO) and Richard Westbury (Chairman of the Chelsea Group).
        </p>
        <p>
         Our core focuses include: smart site services (including portable housing, construction, clean water systems and communication systems), artificial intelligence, technology, cyber and entertainment, and social investment and sport.
        </p>
        <p>
         Enablers and accelerators, we build enterprising partnerships and products across diverse disciplines that powerfully combine to support and advance each other.
        </p>
        <p>
         Visit
         <a href="http://www.enigma-alliance.com/" rel="noopener" target="_blank">
          www.enigma-alliance.com
         </a>
         for more.
        </p>
        <p>
         Enigma Alliance sponsors Ghanian student, Eric Appiah.
        </p>
       </div>

           <path d="M224 416c-8.188 0-16.38-3.125-22.62-9.375l-192-192c-12.5-12.5-12.5-32.75 0-45.25s32.75-12.5 45.25 0L224 338.8l169.4-169.4c12.5-12.5 32.75-12.5 45.25 0s12.5 32.75 0 45.25l-192 192C240.4 412.9 232.2 416 224 416z">
           </path>
          </svg>
         </span>
        </span>
       </summary>
       <div class="cmplz-description">
        <span class="cmplz-description-functional">
         The technical storage or access is strictly necessary for the legitimate purpose of enabling the use of a specific service explicitly requested by the subscriber or user, or for the sole purpose of carrying out the transmission of a communication over an electronic communications network.
        </span>
       </div>
      </details>
      <details class="cmplz-category cmplz-preferences">
       <summary>
        <span class="cmplz-category-header">
         <span class="cmplz-category-title">
          Preferences
         </span>
         <span class="cmplz-banner-checkbox">
          <input class="cmplz-consent-checkbox cmplz-preferences" data-category="cmplz_preferences" id="cmplz-preferences-optin" size="40" type="checkbox" value="1"/>
          <label class="cmplz-label" for="cmplz-preferences-optin" tabindex="0">
           <span class="screen-reader-text">
            Preferences
           </span>
          </label>
         </span>
         <span class="cmplz-icon cmplz-open">
          <svg height="18" viewbox="0 0 448 512" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
           <path d="M224 416c-8.188 0-16.38-3.125-22.62-9.375l-192-192c-12.5-12.5-12.5-32.75 0-45.25s32.75-12.5 45.25 0L224 338.8l169.4-169.4c12.5-12.5 32.75-12.5 45.25 0s12.5 32.75 0 45.25l-192 192C240.4 412.9 232.2 416 224 416z">
           </path>
          </svg>
         </span>
        </span>
       </summary>
       <div class="cmplz-description">
        <span class="cmplz-description-preferences">
         The technical storage or access is necessary for the legitimate purpose of storing preferences that are not requested by the subscriber or user.
        </span>
       </div>
      </details>
      <details class="cmplz-category cmplz-statistics">
       <summary>
        <span class="cmplz-category-header">
         <span class="cmplz-category-title">

           <span class="screen-reader-text">

          </label>
         </span>
         <span class="cmplz-icon cmplz-open">
          <svg height="18" viewbox="0 0 448 512" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
           <path d="M224 416c-8.188 0-16.38-3.125-22.62-9.375l-192-192c-12.5-12.5-12.5-32.75 0-45.25s32.75-12.5 45.25 0L224 338.8l169.4-169.4c12.5-12.5 32.75-12.5 45.25 0s12.5 32.75 0 45.25l-192 192C240.4 412.9 232.2 416 224 416z">
           </path>
          </svg>
         </span>
        </span>
       </summary>
       <div class="cmplz-description">
        <span class="cmplz-description-statistics">
         The technical storage or access that is used exclusively for statistical purposes.
        </span>
        <span class="cmplz-description-statistics-anonymous">
         The technical storage or access that is used exclusively for anonymous statistical purposes. Without a subpoena, voluntary compliance on the part of your Internet Service Provider, or additional records from a third party, information stored or retrieved for this purpose alone cannot usually be used to identify you.
        </span>
       </div>
      </details>
      <details class="cmplz-category cmplz-marketing">
       <summary>
        <span class="cmplz-category-header">
         <span class="cmplz-category-title">

           </path>
          </svg>
         </span>
        </span>

          </span>

         <span class="cmplz-icon cmplz-open">
          <svg height="18" viewbox="0 0 448 512" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">

        </span>
       </div>

Without a subpoena, voluntary compliance on the part of your Internet Service Provider, or additional records from a third party, information stored or retrieved for this purpose alone cannot usually be used to identify you.

       <div class="row" id="row-479891923">
        <div class="col small-12 large-12" id="col-1076503216">
         <div class="col-inner">
          <div class="text" id="text-3299671102">
           <h2>
            WHAT IS MAiSI?
           </h2>
           <p>
            The MAiSI is a full time two year Erasmus Mundus Joint Master Degree in Sports Ethics and Integrity. Innovative and multidisciplinary, the programme is a catalyst for a profession that has been lacking within the sports administration sector. Concentrating on the development of ethical sports cultures and structures, and the development of tools for sports integrity education and compliance, MAiSI is delivered by five prestigious universities in Europe.
           </p>
           <p>
            MAiSI is based on strong theoretical foundations and the development of core competencies needed to develop sports integrity expertise. Scholars are equipped to identify ethical issues, engage in critical ethical thinking, and translate decisions into ethical actions at the highest level of sports governance and administration:
           </p>
           <p>
            Click
            <a href="https://www.maisi-project.eu/masters-degree/">
             here
            </a>
            for more information about the study program, funding and application.
           </p>
           <style>
            #text-3299671102 {
  font-size: 1.1rem;
}
           </style>

     <section class="section" id="section_1548979941">

             <img alt="Sports Ethic Master Semester" class="lazy-load bg attachment-large size-large" data-src="https://sp-ao.shortpixel.ai/client/to_webp,q_glossy,ret_img,w_1020,h_680/https://www.maisi-project.eu/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/shutterstock_251794285.jpg" decoding="async" height="680" src="data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20viewBox%3D%220%200%201020%20680%22%20xmlns%3D%22http%3A%2F%2Fwww.w3.org%2F2000%2Fsvg%22%3E%3C%2Fsvg%3E" width="1020"/>

        <div class="col medium-12 small-12 large-6" id="col-2051574278">
         <div class="col-inner dark">
          <h2>
           SEMESTER ONE: students to be based at KU Leuven
          </h2>
          <p>
           <strong>
            Sport as a Social Practice:
           </strong>
           Norms and values in sport, athlete welfare and safe sport; equality, diversity, and inclusion; moral psychology of sport; disability and Paralympic ethics.
          </p>
          <p>
           <strong>
            The Nature of Sports Ethics and Ethical Theories:
           </strong>
           Deontological, consequentialist and virtue ethical theories; conventionalist, formalist and internalist theories of sport; key issues such as athletes’ rights, fair play and officiating, homophobia, transgender eligibility.
          </p>
          <p>
           <strong>
            Ethics of Anti-doping and Sport Medicine:
           </strong>
           This covers all ethical aspects for anti-doping policy from its rationale to the implementation of the WADA code and other instruments, but also a critical consideration of the ethics of sports medicine more generally. Key issues for discussion include the whereabouts system and rights to privacy, strict liability, fairness and sanctioning, the Therapeutic Exemption process, as well as respect for the best interests of athlete patients, the goals of sports medicine, and the ethics of clinical decision making.
          </p>
          <p>
           <strong>
            Sports law and integrity regulation
           </strong>
           provides a functional and integrated legal approach to sport, conceived as a social phenomenon with social, economic and cultural impact. Particular attention is paid to the unique nature of sports law, a combination of autonomous sports regulation and public regulation.. The course address:  Sources and principles of sports law; conflict resolution in sport; football labour market integrity; fair trial in dispute resolution; integrity, violence and non- discrimination; sports fraud, competition manipulation and macxh-fixing; the law of anti-doping.
          </p>
          <h2>
           SEMESTER TWO: students to be based at CUNI (Prague). Summer School at UoP (Olympia)
          </h2>
          <p>
           <strong>
            Sport Values, Fair Play and Integrity:
           </strong>
           prioritises the explicit development of philosophical and ethical thinking techniques, with discussions on the nature of sport (analytical approaches to the concept of sport and its values); sport rules (and their functions and characteristics); sport categorisations (especially with respect to issues of fairness and justice); and phenomenological understandings of the athlete as a human being. It also applies these theorisations to practical issues of education for sporting integrity.
          </p>
          <p>
           <strong>
            Issues in Disabilities and Paralympic Sports
           </strong>
           covers the Rehabilitation – Education – Active Lifestyle – Elite Sports continuum, including an examination of the history of parasport as a part of rehabilitation. It explains the importance of recognising biomedical impairment types, and the role of adapted physical activities in the rehabilitation process. It also provides an understanding of elite para sport, its organizational structure, classification, and technologies; and considers associated ethical issues. The educational aspect of the parasport active lifestyle of athletes is also discussed, with field visits and practical activities.
          </p>
          <p>
           <strong>
            Research Methods, Knowledge and Competencies:
           </strong>
           This module is held as part of the summer school and introduces students to the major techniques and methods of data capture in social scientific research. This includes questionnaire design and analysis, qualitative interview and focus group techniques. Students also take part in a “dissertation supermarket” talking with supervisors about potential areas of study for their Master thesis.
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
         </div>

     <section class="section" id="section_904945546">
      <div class="section-bg fill">
      </div>
      <div class="section-content relative">
       <div class="row row-collapse row-full-width align-middle" id="row-1390964560">
        <div class="col medium-6 small-12 large-6" id="col-528475717">
         <div class="col-inner">
          <h2>
           SEMESTER THREE: Students to be based at UPF (Barcelona) or JGU (Mainz) depending on their year of entry to the programme
          </h2>
          <p>
           The third semester focuses on in-depth organisational issues that will equip you for the managerial, economic and legal aspects of healthy sports governance. You will also begin your Master thesis in this semester. This entails research topic selection, developing research problems and questions, literature review and preparation of research ethics applications. This semester also focusses on ethical decision making and the challenges international sport federations and major sport event organisers face.
          </p>
          <h2>
           SEMESTER FOUR: Students to be based at any of the Consortium partners depending on their thesis specialism. Summer School at UoP (Olympia)
          </h2>
          <p>
           During the fourth semester, you will have the benefit of being hosted by one of the MAiSI consortium partners to complete your Master thesis. Semester 4 also includes your final taught module in Olympic studies, which is taught as part of the Summer School, and incorporates sites of historical interest from the Ancient Olympic period.
          </p>
         </div>

        <div class="text" id="text-4293650155">
         <h3>
          JOIN A POWERFUL NETWORK OF SECTOR CUSTODIANS
         </h3>
         <style>
          #text-4293650155 {
  font-size: 1.45rem;
  text-align: left;
}
         </style>
        </div>
        <p>
         Through the completion of your EMJMD in Sports Ethics and Integrity (MAiSI), you will join a powerful, international network of partnerships and stakeholders. This network, through their varied roles in the sporting sector, are deeply committed to the promoting of critical engagement and ethical dialogue around the issues facing sports administrations in relation to managing their sports ethics and integrity functions.
        </p>

         <div class="col-inner">
          <div class="text" id="text-364999355">
           <h2>
            WHAT IS MAiSI?
           </h2>
           <p>
            The MAiSI is a full time two year Erasmus Mundus Joint Master Degree in Sports Ethics and Integrity. Innovative and multidisciplinary, the programme is a catalyst for a profession that has been lacking within the sports administration sector. Concentrating on the development of ethical sports cultures and structures, and the development of tools for sports integrity education and compliance, MAiSI is delivered by five prestigious universities in Europe.
           </p>
           <p>
            MAiSI is based on strong theoretical foundations and the development of core competencies needed to develop sports integrity expertise. Scholars are equipped to identify ethical issues, engage in critical ethical thinking, and translate decisions into ethical actions at the highest level of sports governance and administration:
           </p>
           <p>
            Click
            <a href="https://www.maisi-project.eu/masters-degree/">
             here
            </a>
            for more information about the study program, funding and application.
           </p>
           <style>
            #text-364999355 {
  font-size: 1.1rem;
}
           </style>

         </div>

     <section class="section" id="section_1196260328">
      <div class="section-bg fill">
      </div>
      <div class="section-content relative">
       <div class="row row-collapse row-full-width align-middle" id="row-989462575">
        <div class="col medium-12 small-12 large-6" id="col-604333262">
         <div class="col-inner">
          <div class="banner has-hover" id="banner-74396545">
           <div class="banner-inner fill">
            <div class="banner-bg fill">
             <img alt="Sports Ethic Master Semester" class="lazy-load bg attachment-large size-large" data-src="https://sp-ao.shortpixel.ai/client/to_webp,q_glossy,ret_img,w_1020,h_680/https://www.maisi-project.eu/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/shutterstock_251794285.jpg" decoding="async" height="680" src="data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20viewBox%3D%220%200%201020%20680%22%20xmlns%3D%22http%3A%2F%2Fwww.w3.org%2F2000%2Fsvg%22%3E%3C%2Fsvg%3E" width="1020"/>
            </div>
            <div class="banner-layers container">
             <div class="fill banner-link">
             </div>
             <div class="text-box banner-layer x50 md-x50 lg-x50 y50 md-y50 lg-y50 res-text" id="text-box-154565745">
              <div class="text-box-content text dark">
               <div class="text-inner text-center">
               </div>

        <div class="col medium-12 small-12 large-6" id="col-1180120756">
         <div class="col-inner dark">
          <h2>
           SEMESTER ONE: students to be based at KU Leuven
          </h2>
          <p>
           <strong>
            Sport as a Social Practice:
           </strong>
           Norms and values in sport, athlete welfare and safe sport; equality, diversity, and inclusion; moral psychology of sport; disability and Paralympic ethics.
          </p>
          <p>
           <strong>
            The Nature of Sports Ethics and Ethical Theories:
           </strong>
           Deontological, consequentialist and virtue ethical theories; conventionalist, formalist and internalist theories of sport; key issues such as athletes’ rights, fair play and officiating, homophobia, transgender eligibility.
          </p>
          <p>
           <strong>
            Ethics of Anti-doping and Sport Medicine:
           </strong>
           This covers all ethical aspects for anti-doping policy from its rationale to the implementation of the WADA code and other instruments, but also a critical consideration of the ethics of sports medicine more generally. Key issues for discussion include the whereabouts system and rights to privacy, strict liability, fairness and sanctioning, the Therapeutic Exemption process, as well as respect for the best interests of athlete patients, the goals of sports medicine, and the ethics of clinical decision making.
          </p>
          <p>
           <strong>
            Sports law and integrity regulation
           </strong>
           provides a functional and integrated legal approach to sport, conceived as a social phenomenon with social, economic and cultural impact. Particular attention is paid to the unique nature of sports law, a combination of autonomous sports regulation and public regulation.. The course address:  Sources and principles of sports law; conflict resolution in sport; football labour market integrity; fair trial in dispute resolution; integrity, violence and non- discrimination; sports fraud, competition manipulation and macxh-fixing; the law of anti-doping.
          </p>
          <h2>
           SEMESTER TWO: students to be based at CUNI (Prague). Summer School at UoP (Olympia)
          </h2>
          <p>
           <strong>
            Sport Values, Fair Play and Integrity:
           </strong>
           prioritises the explicit development of philosophical and ethical thinking techniques, with discussions on the nature of sport (analytical approaches to the concept of sport and its values); sport rules (and their functions and characteristics); sport categorisations (especially with respect to issues of fairness and justice); and phenomenological understandings of the athlete as a human being. It also applies these theorisations to practical issues of education for sporting integrity.
          </p>
          <p>
           <strong>
            Issues in Disabilities and Paralympic Sports
           </strong>
           covers the Rehabilitation – Education – Active Lifestyle – Elite Sports continuum, including an examination of the history of parasport as a part of rehabilitation. It explains the importance of recognising biomedical impairment types, and the role of adapted physical activities in the rehabilitation process. It also provides an understanding of elite para sport, its organizational structure, classification, and technologies; and considers associated ethical issues. The educational aspect of the parasport active lifestyle of athletes is also discussed, with field visits and practical activities.
          </p>
          <p>
           <strong>
            Research Methods, Knowledge and Competencies:
           </strong>
           This module is held as part of the summer school and introduces students to the major techniques and methods of data capture in social scientific research. This includes questionnaire design and analysis, qualitative interview and focus group techniques. Students also take part in a “dissertation supermarket” talking with supervisors about potential areas of study for their Master thesis.
          </p>
          <p>
          </p>
         </div>

     <section class="section" id="section_1167138082">
      <div class="section-bg fill">
      </div>
      <div class="section-content relative">
       <div class="row row-collapse row-full-width align-middle" id="row-1404712298">
        <div class="col medium-6 small-12 large-6" id="col-1258587356">
         <div class="col-inner">
          <h2>
           SEMESTER THREE: Students to be based at UPF (Barcelona) or JGU (Mainz) depending on their year of entry to the programme
          </h2>
          <p>
           The third semester focuses on in-depth organisational issues that will equip you for the managerial, economic and legal aspects of healthy sports governance. You will also begin your Master thesis in this semester. This entails research topic selection, developing research problems and questions, literature review and preparation of research ethics applications. This semester also focusses on ethical decision making and the challenges international sport federations and major sport event organisers face.
          </p>
          <h2>
           SEMESTER FOUR: Students to be based at any of the Consortium partners depending on their thesis specialism. Summer School at UoP (Olympia)
          </h2>
          <p>
           During the fourth semester, you will have the benefit of being hosted by one of the MAiSI consortium partners to complete your Master thesis. Semester 4 also includes your final taught module in Olympic studies, which is taught as part of the Summer School, and incorporates sites of historical interest from the Ancient Olympic period.
          </p>
         </div>

         <h3>

  text-align: left;

        <p>
         Through the completion of your EMJMD in Sports Ethics and Integrity (MAiSI), you will join a powerful, international network of partnerships and stakeholders.
